title: Syllabus
text:
Term: Fall 2023
Instructor: Isaac Quintanilla Salinas
Email: isaac.qs@csuci.edu
Office Location: BTE 2840
Office Hours:



OH
Course
R Programming
TEA Math/Stat Hour




Day
MW
Tue
Th


Location
BT 1462
LRC
BTE Courtyard


Time
4:30-6:00 PM
10-12 AM
12-1:30 PM



Or by Zoom appointment.
Lecture: Monday/Wednesday 10:00-11:50 AM (Sec 01) or 2:00-3:50 PM (Sec 02) in BT 1462



Critical reasoning using a quantitative and statistical, problem-solving approach to solving real-world problems. Topics include: probability and statistics, sample data, probability and empirical data distributions, sampling techniques, estimation and hypothesis testing, ANOVA, and correlation and regression analysis. Students will use standard statistical software to analyze real-world and simulated data. GenEd: B4




Prepare students for advanced courses in data-management and statistics
Reason both inductively and deductively with quantitative information and data
Use statistical software for complex statistical analysis of real-world and simulated data
Empower students to apply computational and inferential thinking to address real-world problems
Write the results of a statistical study and draw conclusion in reports




This course will use Coursekata, a Canvas-embedded textbook with built-in R functionality.



For this course, we will use R and RStudio. You will have access to them online, but you may download and install them on your computer.

R is a free statistical software program that is available for download at: https://www.r-project.org/.
RStudio provides free and open source tools for your data analysis in R: https://www.rstudio.com/




This course will have two embedded peer educators:

Devin Frost (Sec 01)

Email: devin.frost091@csuci.edu

Amanda Parks (Sec 02)

Email: amanda.parks743@myci.csuci.edu


An EPE is there to help you understand the material and succeed in the course. They will be leading in class assignments. hold special tutoring sessions, and support you in your R programming. These educators are trained with study skills that will set you up with success in college.

Participation is based on short writing assignments conducted in class. There will be no make ups for these writing prompts.



Lab assignments are designed to expand your statistical knowledge. These will be completed in JupyterHub which can be accessed from Canvas. There are approximately 2 lab assignments every week that you can complete during class time. The lab assignment will be due either on Tuesday or Thursday at 11:59 PM following the lab day it was assigned.



Reading assignments are designed to teach you different statistical concepts and R Programming. As the course progresses, many of the concepts build on each other. Therefore, the assignments encourage you to read each chapter in an appropriate amount of time. You must read the chapter and answer the questions by the Sunday night at 11:59 PM. The 2 lowest reading assignments will be dropped.



Starting on Week 2, there will be a weekly quiz every Friday. The quiz will become available for you to take on Canvas at 12AM to 11:59 PM every Friday. The quiz is designed to test whether you recall the material from the previous week. You are expected to complete the quiz with out using any material such as your notes, textbook, or internet. Additionally, you will get 90% of the quiz grade for simply taking the quiz. The remaining 10% is based on getting the question correct. There are a total of 12 quizzes in the semester. The lowest 3 quizzes will be dropped from your class grade. There are no make up quizzes.



There will be three in exams. Exam #1 will on Sept 25, Exam #2 will be on Nov 8, and Exam #3 will be on Dec 6 at 8-10 AM (Sec 01) or 1-3 PM (Sec 02). While the exams are not considered cumulative, the material builds on each other. Developing a strong understanding of the material through out the course is important for your success. At the end of the semester, your lowest exam grade will be replaced by your median average exam grade. This course will operate under a zero-tolerance policy. Talking during the time of the exam, sharing materials, looking at another students’ exam, or not following directions given will be subject to the University’s academic integrity policy.



There will be 3 extra credit opportunities worth a total of 10% of your overall grade. (There are no make-ups for missed extra credit assignments!) More information will be provided on the extra credit assignments on a later date. Information on the extra credit can be found here.




The following outline may be subject to change. Any changes will be announced in class.

Academic Honesty:
Please conduct yourself with honesty and integrity. Do not submit others’ work as your own. For assignments and quizzes that allow you to work with a group, only put your name on what the group submits if you genuinely contributed to the work. Work completely independently on exams, using only the materials that are indicated as allowed. Failure to observe academic honesty results in substantial penalties that can include failing the course.
Disabilities:
If you are a student with a disability requesting reasonable accommodations in this course, you need to contact Disability Accommodations and Support Services (DASS) located on the second floor of Arroyo Hall, via email accommodations@csuci.edu or call 805-437-3331. All requests for reasonable accommodations require registration with DASS in advance of need: https://www.csuci.edu/dass/students/apply-for-services.htm. Faculty, students and DASS will work together regarding classroom accommodations. You are encouraged to discuss approved.
Emergency Procedure Notice to Students:
CSUCI is following guidelines and public orders from the California Department of Public Health and Ventura County Public Health for the COVID-19 pandemic as it pertains to CSUCI students, employees and visitors on the campus. Students are expected to adhere to all health and safety requirements as noted on the University’s Spring 2023 Semester website or they may be subject to removal from the classroom.




The California Faculty Association (the labor union of Lecturers, Professors, Coaches, Counselors, and Librarians across the 23 CSU campuses) is in a difficult contract dispute with California State University management. It is possible that we will call a strike or other work stoppage this term. I promise to promptly inform you of any schedule disruption. Our working conditions are your learning conditions; we seek to protect both. For further information go to www.CFAbargaining.org.

title: Welcome!
text:
Sampling
Sampling is the process of selecting units from a population interest to collect data from.

title: Welcome!
text:
Sampling
When Sampling you want to maintain these properties:

Representative sample
Large enough sample size

title: Welcome!
text:
Sampling Example
We want to answer the question, are people happy?

title: Welcome!
text:
Random Sampling
When sampling, we strive for random sampling

Each unit in the population of interest must have an equal probability of being selected for the study.
This ensures a representative population

title: Welcome!
text:
Independent Sampling
In addition to random sampling, we strive to make sure each unit is independent from each other.

The probability of UNIT A being sampled will not affect the probability of UNIT B to be sampled.

title: Welcome!
text:
Sampling Variation

Random samples may vary from the population of interest.
Due to randomness, samples many not look the or biased.
However, this is to be expected as because the sample will not be biased in one way or another.
Samples are then considered unbiased as long as experimental units were collected randomly.

title: Welcome!
text: Data Structure

title: Welcome!
text:
Data
A data set can be manipulated in ways to make it easier to process:

filter(): allows you to remove rows that do not satisfy a certain condition
select(): select to view certain variables
mutate(): add a new variable to the data set based on a set of instructions

title: Welcome!
text:
Selecting a Variable
I am interested in viewing species, island, and body_mass_g in my data set:

select(penguins, species, island, body_mass_g)

#> # A tibble: 344 × 3
#>    species island    body_mass_g
#>    <fct>   <fct>           <int>
#>  1 Adelie  Torgersen        3750
#>  2 Adelie  Torgersen        3800
#>  3 Adelie  Torgersen        3250
#>  4 Adelie  Torgersen          NA
#>  5 Adelie  Torgersen        3450
#>  6 Adelie  Torgersen        3650
#>  7 Adelie  Torgersen        3625
#>  8 Adelie  Torgersen        4675
#>  9 Adelie  Torgersen        3475
#> 10 Adelie  Torgersen        4250
#> # ℹ 334 more rows

title: Welcome!
text:
Filtering a Data Set
I am only interested in looking at the penguins with a body mass bigger than 4000 g:

penguins_over_4000 <- filter(penguins, body_mass_g > 4000)
select(penguins_over_4000, species, island, body_mass_g)

#> # A tibble: 172 × 3
#>    species island    body_mass_g
#>    <fct>   <fct>           <int>
#>  1 Adelie  Torgersen        4675
#>  2 Adelie  Torgersen        4250
#>  3 Adelie  Torgersen        4400
#>  4 Adelie  Torgersen        4500
#>  5 Adelie  Torgersen        4200
#>  6 Adelie  Dream            4150
#>  7 Adelie  Dream            4650
#>  8 Adelie  Dream            4400
#>  9 Adelie  Dream            4600
#> 10 Adelie  Dream            4150
#> # ℹ 162 more rows

title: Welcome!
text:
Data Manipulation
This is a process where we can manipulate the data when there are errors in the data recording process.
OR
Data must be formatted in a way for analysis (computer requirements).

title: Welcome!
text: Missing Data

title: Welcome!
text:
Handling Missing Data
How do we handle missing data?

Remove the experimental unit
Take and educated guess what it is

Replace with mean
Single Imputation
Multiple Imputation

title: Welcome!
text:
Handling Missing Data
For this class, we will remove the entire experimental unit.

# Obtaining the number of rows
nrow(penguins)

#> [1] 344

# Removing missing cases
penguins_missing_removed <- drop_na(penguins)
nrow(penguins_missing_removed)

#> [1] 333

title: Welcome!
text:
Summarizing Data


#> [1] 14.14 12.54 15.74 12.83  7.94  1.59 11.06  8.85


How would a computer count how many values are greater than 10?

title: Welcome!
text:
Prediction
3, 4, 6, 2, 7, 9, 2, 0, 1, 4, 6, 2
List as many ways you can present the data to collaborators. With each method, what are the advantages and disadvantages?

title: Welcome!
text:
Math Minds

Math MINDS is open to motivated Channel Islands students enrolled in a B4 Quantitative reasoning course this semester. This FREE transformative program includes:

A $350 scholarship award (payable upon completion of the program requirements)
Four workshops early in the semester to develop your mathematical ability with active learning

Weeks 4 through 8 of the semester

Individualized skill development through a minimum of four one-on-one tutoring sessions with Learning Resource Center tutors

Minimum of two tutoring sessions before Week 6 of the semester
Minimum of two additional tutoring sessions before Week 12 of the semester

A short asynchronous online course about learning mathematics
Four MasterMINDS Group Check-In Meetings

Weeks 9 through 15 of the semester

Support to build long-lasting strength and confidence in your mathematical ability
A chance to make new friends and strengthen your college journey!

title: Extra Credit 3
text:
Provide a summary of one book below, an write a brief analysis in supporting or opposing the book, and a personal reaction of the book. Some of these books are available through the Broome Library.
Books:

The Book of Why

Judea Pearl

Algorithms of Oppression

Safiya Umoja Noble

Data Feminism

Catherine D’Ignazio and Lauren Klein

Weapons of Math Destruction

Cathy O’Niel

Invisible women : data bias in a world designed for men

Caroline Criado Perez

Factfulness: Ten Reasons We’re Wrong About the World… and Why Things are Better Than You Think

Hans Rosling

Artificial Unintelligence: How Computers Misunderstand the World

Merideth Broussard

Technically Wrong: Sexist Apps, Biased Algorithms, and Other Threats of Toxic Tech

Sara Wachter-Boettcher


Report guidelines

5-6 Pages
Must include a title page
Double Spaced
12 point font
Proofread your work
Submit a pdf of your work to Canvas
Due 12/4/2023

Worth 4 final grade percentage points.

Provide a summary of one book below, an write a brief analysis in supporting or opposing the book, and a personal reaction of the book. The majority of these books are available through the Broome Library.
Books:

Happiness: A Guide to Developing Life’s

Matthieu Ricard

Grit: The Power of Passion and Perserverance

Angela Duckworth

Mindset: The New Psychology of Success

Carol Dweck


Report guidelines

5-6 Pages
Must include a title page
Double Spaced
12 point font
Proofread your work
Submit a pdf of your work to Canvas
Due 12/4/2023

Worth 3 final grade percentage points.

title: Welcome to Elementary Statistics!
text:
Brief Introduction





Welcome to the course! This is the home page of the course where I will provide a recap on what was covered in the week. Here I will post any documents or videos for your reference. If you have any questions, please email me at isaac.qs@csuci.edu.









Introduction to Statistics Book





https://www.openintro.org/book/os/

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Learning Outcomes

Announcements
Data
Measurements
Penguins

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Expected Study Time
You should spend 2-3 hours per unit of registered class.
For Math 201, spend 8-12 hours to succeed.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Math Minds

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Population
A population is the entire group that we want to know more about.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Sample
A sample is a subset of a population that is considered representative.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Sample vs Population

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Experimental Unit
An experimental unit is one individual unit from a sample.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Data
Data is information from a particular experimental unit. There can be more that one piece of information per experimental unit.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Data Structure
The structure of the data can be represented in various forms:

A list of long numbers
Table

title: Numbers & Data
text: Tabular Form

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Measurements
Measurements are the processes where we represent an attribute of an experimental unit as either a number or category.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Quantitative Measurements
Quantitative measurements are data measurements that take a numeric form.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Qualitative Measurements
Qualitative measurements are data measurements that take a certain category.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Value
A value is a description (number or category) of a specific attribute of an experimental unit.

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Variable
A variable is the descriptive attribute that we want to obtain from an experimental unit. In terms of a data set, the variable contains all the values of specific attribute in a sample.

title: Numbers & Data
text: Penguin

title: Numbers & Data
text: Penguins

title: Numbers & Data
text: Palmer Penguins

title: Numbers & Data
text:
Prediction
When you are given a large data set, what numbers do you want to know about?
What would these numbers tell you about the data?
